Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Deformation Mechanisms in Hierarchical Metallic Nano-Lattices: Experimental and Computational Study

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to elucidate the fundamental deformation mechanisms that govern the overall mechanical properties of material systems with competing material- and structure-induced size effects. Crystalline solids have been shown to exhibit both intrinsic/material size effects, such as the grain-size dependent strength of polycrystals, as well as extrinsic/structure-induced size effects, such as the size-dependent strength of single-crystalline micro- and nano-pillars. While both types of size effects have been studied independently, the mechanical response of material systems in which macro-structural feature size and characteristic size of the microstructure merge is a key open question for two reasons. First, experimental techniques for fabricating and testing micro- and particularly nano-scale structures are intricate and often require specialized facilities. Second, most computational models fail to describe physical phenomena, which require both a discrete atomistic description and realistic (i.e. experimentally accessible) temporal and spatial resolution. This research project will combine advanced computational models for coarse-graining atomistic simulations with novel fabrication and in situ experimental methods to synthesize and test hollow metallic nano-trusses, which will give insight into the governing deformation mechanisms and the resulting mechanical properties of nano-structural materials.

If successful, the outcome of this interdisciplinary collaborative research will be transformative in the synthesis of new materials with highly desirable properties, which have been historically coupled in limiting combinations (e.g. stiffness and weight). The gained knowledge promises to be essential for the development and improvement of structural materials, and it makes a prime example to illustrate the importance of structure-property relations in solids, which will be included in classroom and high school education. This project will train undergraduate students from both engineering and physics backgrounds through interdisciplinary research projects with special emphasis on recruiting students from underrepresented groups and women. Broad outreach activities geared towards K-12 students will offer opportunities to become involved, including a summer program for high school students who are invited to spend three to six weeks working in the labs. The PIs will provide training and career development for graduate students in an exciting interdisciplinary field to combine materials phenomena with theory and experiments. Finally, the integrated and iterative computational and experimental tasks will make a prime example for successful interdisciplinary research to close a knowledge gap across scientific disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The creation of extremely stiff and strong yet ultralight materials has been achieved by capitalizing on the hi­e­r­a­­r­chical design of nanotrusses which promise superb ther­mo­mechanical pro­­­per­­ties at ex­tre­me­ly low mass densities (lighter than aerogels), making these solid foams ideal for many scientific and tech­no­lo­gi­cal applications. Since the structure-property relations of this novel type of metamaterial were entirely unknown, our investigation aimed at a comprehensive understanding of the physical mecha­nisms governing the mechanical properties of three-dimensional periodic and hierarchical nano-structures (i.e. with maximum dimensions of structural members below 1 micron), where competing material- and structure-induced size effects drive overall properties.

To this end, we employed advanced fa­brica­tion and nano-mecha­nical in-situ testing methodologies to create and characterize three material systems: solid polymer, hollow ceramic or metallic, and composites (polymer core with ceramic or metallic coating), and we developed and applied new com­pu­ta­tional models for both macroscopic and atomic-scale simulations of nanotrusses.

Our experi­ments developed a nano-truss fa­bri­ca­tion and testing me­tho­dology by utili­zing a combination of polymeric truss skeleton fabrication, electroless metal/ceramic deposition, erosion of the polymer (where necessary), and in-situ nano-mecha­ni­cal testing. Mo­no­tonic and cyclic tests shed light on defor­mation processes and size- and material-induced mecha­nical properties and provided a one-to-one comparison with simu­la­tions via itera­tive loops.

Our simulations deployed two newly-developed types of multiscale techniques. First, we used a domain decomposition method at the continuum level which efficiently predicted the stiffness of hierarchical nanotrusses containing thousands to millions of individual truss members. Second, we developed a fully-nonlocal quasicontinuum method which coarse-grains atomistic ensembles and thereby enables simulations based solely on atomistic potentials at significantly larger length scales than what is accessible by atomistic techniques such as, e.g., molecular dynamics. Both techniques were applied to nanotrusses and their underlying material systems to elucidate deformation and failure mechanisms in coordination with experiments.

Our results show, among others, a nearly theoretical scaling of structural strength and stiffness with relative nanotruss density, which outperforms existing non-hierarchical nanolattices. We also showed extreme cases of nanotruss recoverability, with hollow alumina samples recovering up to 98% of their original height after compression to more than 50% strain. Experiments also revealed the suppression of brittle failure and structural instabilities in hollow hierarchical nanolattices, as well as the flaw-insensitivity of pre-notched nanolattices with sufficiently low wall thicknesses. Overall, we showed that the range of observable deformation mechanisms can be tuned by, among others, changing the slenderness ratios of the beams.

Overall, this project has resulted in new mul­ti­scale mode­ling methodology, experimental fabrication and testing techniques, and a new class of mechanical nanoscale metamaterials with exciting structure-property relations not commonly found in micro- and macroscale counterparts. Most importantly, the project has revealed new understanding for the deformation and failure mechanisms in hierarchical and periodic nanotrusses, of importance for the creation of new materials with highly desirable properties, his...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The creation of extremely stiff and strong yet ultralight materials has been achieved by capitalizing on the hi­e­r­a­­r­chical design of nanotrusses which promise superb ther­mo­mechanical pro­­­per­­ties at ex­tre­me­ly low mass densities (lighter than aerogels), making these solid foams ideal for many scientific and tech­no­lo­gi­cal applications. Since the structure-property relations of this novel type of metamaterial were entirely unknown, our investigation aimed at a comprehensive understanding of the physical mecha­nisms governing the mechanical properties of three-dimensional periodic and hierarchical nano-structures (i.e. with maximum dimensions of structural members below 1 micron), where competing material- and structure-induced size effects drive overall properties. To this end, we employed advanced fa­brica­tion and nano-mecha­nical in-situ testing methodologies to create and characterize three material systems: solid polymer, hollow ceramic or metallic, and composites (polymer core with ceramic or metallic coating), and we developed and applied new com­pu­ta­tional models for both macroscopic and atomic-scale simulations of nanotrusses. Our experi­ments developed a nano-truss fa­bri­ca­tion and testing me­tho­dology by utili­zing a combination of polymeric truss skeleton fabrication, electroless metal/ceramic deposition, erosion of the polymer (where necessary), and in-situ nano-mecha­ni­cal testing. Mo­no­tonic and cyclic tests shed light on defor­mation processes and size- and material-induced mecha­nical properties and provided a one-to-one comparison with simu­la­tions via itera­tive loops. Our simulations deployed two newly-developed types of multiscale techniques. First, we used a domain decomposition method at the continuum level which efficiently predicted the stiffness of hierarchical nanotrusses containing thousands to millions of individual truss members. Second, we developed a fully-nonlocal quasicontinuum method which coarse-grains atomistic ensembles and thereby enables simulations based solely on atomistic potentials at significantly larger length scales than what is accessible by atomistic techniques such as, e.g., molecular dynamics. Both techniques were applied to nanotrusses and their underlying material systems to elucidate deformation and failure mechanisms in coordination with experiments. Our results show, among others, a nearly theoretical scaling of structural strength and stiffness with relative nanotruss density, which outperforms existing non-hierarchical nanolattices. We also showed extreme cases of nanotruss recoverability, with hollow alumina samples recovering up to 98% of their original height after compression to more than 50% strain. Experiments also revealed the suppression of brittle failure and structural instabilities in hollow hierarchical nanolattices, as well as the flaw-insensitivity of pre-notched nanolattices with sufficiently low wall thicknesses. Overall, we showed that the range of observable deformation mechanisms can be tuned by, among others, changing the slenderness ratios of the beams. Overall, this project has resulted in new mul­ti­scale mode­ling methodology, experimental fabrication and testing techniques, and a new class of mechanical nanoscale metamaterials with exciting structure-property relations not commonly found in micro- and macroscale counterparts. Most importantly, the project has revealed new understanding for the deformation and failure mechanisms in hierarchical and periodic nanotrusses, of importance for the creation of new materials with highly desirable properties, historically coupled in limiting combinations (e.g., stiffness and weight). Outcomes of this research were included in classroom education and in high school outreach programs at Caltech. Fo...
